content.description: The long slab face through arches to the summit. I didn't get around to doing this climb. Start on the slab of W5 and belay. Head straight up slab to arch and surmount it to belay. Climb directly up again on slab (crux possibly 5-11) and surmount another arch to belay. climb slab again to the tree ledges to exit.
content.location: high up the left side of the tongue is the nose buttress by dirt gully. Left of the nose slab start.

content.description:
This route parallels Jupiter to the right all the way to the top of the cliff.Pitch 1. 50m 5.11a bolts only, perfect slab pitch, you can start it on the left via 5.6 crack or straight up through old homemade black hanger (5.10 moves on the left side of the hanger) Â  Pitch 2. ~40m 5.10 bolts and gear Pitch 3. ~30m 5.9 Pitch 4 ~30m 5.9 (p.3/4 can be barely linked with 60m) Pitch 5 ~35m 5.9 Pitch 6 ~30m 5.9 (don't link them)To top out - From the alcove with the tree ledge traverse left on a large block and clip a bolt over a roof. Step over the roof and clip another bolt, and run it to the trees topping out the cliff. 5.6 and a little dirty 

 otherwise, from the top of pitch 6 rappel down using two 60m ropes Rappel 1: from p6 anchor to p4 straight down. Rappel 2: from p4 anchor to p2 Then obvious.
content.protection: All the pitches have bolted anchors at the top of every pitch. Any place that does not have natural pro has bolts.
content.location: Approach: When the trail hits the cliff, hike left and up to the bottom of a slab with a black homemade hanger bolt 15" up.

content.description: The Jupiter Area is the yin to the Big Walls yang. The routes can be just as long, or longer, than the Big Wall but not as severe. The lower angle, ledges and numerous trees reduce some of the exposure. Routes are generally in the 5.10 range and well bolted with modern hardware.
